clinical_validity.disease_label: NACC1-related neurodevelopmental disorder with epilepsy, cataracts and episodic irritability

generif.text: NAC-1 is a tumor recurrence-associated gene with oncogenic potential; interactions between BTB/POZ domains of NAC-1 proteins are critical to form the discrete NAC-1 nuclear bodies and essential for tumor cell proliferation and survival.
NAC-1 expression is higher in ovarian carcinoma cells in effusions compared with their solid tumor counterparts.
NAC-1 contributes to tumor growth and survival by at least inhibiting Gadd45GIP1 expression, which has a tumor suppressor effect in cancer cells.
NAC-1 may play an important role in cervical carcinomas.
NAC-1 regulates Taxol resistance in ovarian cancer
Therefore, we conclude that NAC1 functions as a corepressor for POZ/BTB proteins expressed in the mature CNS.
NAC-1, a potential stem cell pluripotency factor, contributes to paclitaxel resistance in ovarian cancer by inactivating Gadd45v pathway.
C-terminal alpha-helix of the Nac1 POZ domain is shorter than that observed in most other POZ-domain transcription factors
NAC1 is a potential stem cell pluripotency factor expression in normal endometrium, endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma

NAC1 over-expression is critical to the growth and survival of ovarian cancers. Furthermore, they suggest that NAC1 silencing RNA-induced phenotypes depend on the expression status of the targeted cell line.
Our data suggest that amplification at the ch19p13.2 NACC1 locus, leading to NAC1 overexpression, is one of the molecular genetic alterations associated with early tumor recurrence in ovarian cancer.
These results indicate that a cell cycle-dependent regulatory mechanism controls NAC1 body formation in the nucleus and suggest that NAC1 body dynamics are associated with mitosis or cytokinesis.

These data suggest that the acetylation status of CTTN modulated by the NACC1-HDAC6 deacetylation system induces acceleration of melanoma cell migration activity via an actin-dependent cellular process
NAC1 is identified as a novel regulator of autophagy
NAC1 overexpression is critical to the growth and survival of cervical carcinomas irrespective of histologic type.
NAC1 expression was significantly correlated with FASN expression in both OCCC samples and OCCC cell lines.

Results not only reveal a previously unrecognized function of NAC1, the molecular pathway involved and its impact on pathogenesis of tumor initiation and development, but also identify a novel senescence regulator
The identification of an NAC1 NLS thus clarifies the mechanism through which NAC1 translocates to the nucleus to regulate the transcription of genes involved in oncogenicity and pluripotency.
Uterine sarcomas with NAC1 overexpression are clinically the most aggressive, chemoresistant, and radioresistant tumors.
low expression of NAC1 predicts poor prognosis for patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
NAC1 is essential and sufficient for activation of FOXQ1
strategy for the purification of tethered POZ domains that form forced heterodimers is described, and crystal structures of the heterodimeric POZ domains of Miz1/BCL6 and of Miz1/NAC1 are reported
NACC1 can be modified by SUMO paralogues, and cooperates with promyelocytic leukemia protein.
NAC1 has potential as a marker for distinguishing OED from CIS/OSCC

miR-339-5p inhibits migration and invasion in ovarian cancer by targeting NACC1 and BCL6. miR-339-5p may be a biomarker of metastasis in ovarian cancer; NACC1 had a predictive value for ovarian cancer progression
NAC1 forms a protein complex to function as a transcriptional regulator in cancer cells

a mutation in NACC1 causes microcephaly, profound developmental delays and/or intellectual disability, cataracts, severe epilepsy including infantile spasms, irritability, failure to thrive, and stereotypic hand movements
knockdown of HOXA9 abrogated NAC1induced drug resistance.
NAC1/ HMGB1 signaling pathway is associated with the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), invasion, and metastasis of lung cancer cells.
LINC00319 promotes ovarian cancer progression through upregulating NACC1 expression by restraining miR-423-5p.

We identified human nucleus accumbens-associated 1 (NAC1), a member of the BTB/POZ family, as a bridge for MAVS and TBK1 that positively regulates the RIG-I-like receptors-mediated induction of type I IFN
NACC-1 regulates hepatocellular carcinoma cell malignancy and is targeted by miR-760.
NAC1 attenuates BCL6 negative autoregulation and functions as a BCL6 coactivator of FOXQ1 transcription in cancer cells.
lncRNA FOXP4AS1 predicts poor prognosis and accelerates the progression of mantle cell lymphoma through the miR4235p/NACC1 pathway.
Unclassified low grade spindle cell sarcoma with storiform pattern characterized by recurrent novel EWSR1/FUS-NACC1 fusions.
FUS-induced circRHOBTB3 facilitates cell proliferation via miR-600/NACC1 mediated autophagy response in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
Mechanistic insights of NAC1 nuclear export and its role in ovarian cancer resistance to docetaxel.
An overview of the co-transcription factor NACC1: Beyond its pro-tumor effects.
Hyperkinetic Movement Disorder Caused by the Recurrent c.892C>T NACC1 Variant.

name: nucleus accumbens associated 1
other_names: nucleus accumbens associated 1, BEN and BTB (POZ) domain containing
summary: This gene encodes a member of the BTB/POZ protein family. BTB/POZ proteins are involved in several cellular processes including proliferation, apoptosis and transcription regulation. The encoded protein is a transcriptional repressor that plays a role in stem cell self-renewal and pluripotency maintenance. The encoded protein also suppresses transcription of the candidate tumor suppressor Gadd45GIP1, and expression of this gene may play a role in the progression of multiple types of cancer. A pseudogene of this gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 9. [provided by RefSeq, Feb 2012].
